												This is one of those games you have laying around your place, and your friend boots it up while he's waiting for you to get ready to go somewhere. Cheap laughs, fun to play, with lots of gore, but after watching crowds of zombies be cut up by a lawn mower blade for the 150th time, the game can lose its charm. Being able to pick up anything off the ground and use it as a weapon is definitly fun, but you slowly start to realise really how little of them actually benefit you. You'd think having hundreds of ways to kill a zombie would be good for some mindeless fun, and it is for the first few hours... but soon enough it grows tedious, and soon you find the zombies are just a bunch of traffic cones that you can easily kick over as they constantly get in your way. They add little challenge to the game, and are literally just walking manaquins for you to unleash your boyhood fantasies of drawing dead stick figuers a hundred times on a blank sheet of paper with a red marker. Its fun, but don't expect something perminant, the gimic of zombie killing wears down quickly, and as soon as you run out of objects to play around with, mowing down zombies is about as exciting as mowing down a lawn, tedious and just a lot of work.  Fortunatly when you get to that point, (and believe me you will) There are several unique and challenging boss fights or psychopaths to take on with your aresonal of orange juice and brooms with a machetes duct taped to the ends. Each one shows signs of multiple psychiatric discorders to reflect the grievance of whatever situation they are cought in. These psychopaths easily steal the show, and I found myself attempting to hunt down each one of them, as each of them were unique, varied, with different weapons and personalities.      I can't exactly say the same for the main story though... This time around in contrast to dead rising 2, you play as Frank West in an alternate story line where he is lazily strapped into the same scenes as Chuck Greene was in from the main game. All the side characters basicaly share almost exactly the same diologue, while Frank might change up a few of Chuck Greene's original lines. You'll more then likely play the main story once then blow it off completely in future attempts of the game as its nothing special, and you probably didn't pick this game up for an enthralling story in the first place. Sorry Frank,, but you're little crysis is as lame as your cheezy one liners. At least with this incardnation of Dead Rising 2, it comes with several DLCs free of charge, and a whole section of the map that was previously blocked off in the vanilla game. Other then that, its nearly the exact same game, just with an alternate story line.If you enjoy violance with all the blood and gore to bath yourself with, then you'll enjoy all your common household objects duct tapped to pointy things as you mindlessly slay walking targets in as multiple ways as the game allows. Fun and cheap, you might come back to it every once in a while for some mindless zombie killing, but without real challenge, it' won't be long before the fun of zombie slaying soon becomes a chore and this game drifts back into your library and remains untouched in till that one bored friend comes over and boots it up. 7.5/10

												Dead Rising 2: Off The Record is a hard game to judge.  Dead Rising 2 was a good game, the problem with Dead Rising 2 is that it's the same game.  By that I don't mean "Oh they reused the assets" or "They used the same map".  Both of those are acceptable.  No Dead Rising 2: Off the Record, literally did a character swap and changed less than a third of the story. To be honest, this should not have been it's own game.  This is almost DLC masquerading as a full release.  There is some other changes (a few more survivors, a few changes to survivors, I think a few new psychopaths)  but if you've played Dead Rising 2 right before this game, this is going to be like a second playthrough of Dead Rising. As for the story, there's really two major changes that I noticed.  Instead of Chuck being blamed for releasing zombies, another person is blamed.  (A character that appears in the original game).  And the ending.  The final boss, (literally the final scene) is different, with a significantly change to the ending. There is one new (and rather large) area that is added to the game, that is a nice addition, but it's just that, an addition, not a whole new world. Other than that, the game, majority of psychopathes and majority of the mall is the same.  You're seeing similar people doing similar things, and fighting similar enemies. So there's really three ways to look at it. If you played Dead Rising 1 and want to play Dead Rising 2, I would recommend Off The Record, over Dead Rising 2. If you played Dead Rising 2, you likely will not want to play Off The Record. If you played Dead Rising 2 but the whole time thought "I want to play as Frank West" Then Dead Rising 2 Off the Record is for you. It's not a BAD game, it's fully functional, vastly improves on Dead Rising 2 (You don't have to stand still to talk to Otis, who is not in this version, you get a really functional ear piece as well).  The achievements are better as well, the game works well, and you don't have to constantly return to the hideout to give Zombrex to Katie (what an awful gameplay element that was). If you don't have Dead Rising 2, this is the better version.  If you do... I find it hard to recommend this version as you already have a working game.  It's not a bad, and I can't not recommend Dead Rising 2: Off the Record because it does nothing wrong.  But it is quite a bit of a cash grab for Capcom, and honestly they could have told an all new story.  A shame, because this is a rather fun series.  Still I had a blast replaying Dead Rising 2 as I played it when it first came out, and for that.  Off the Record delivered exactly what it promised.  A retelling of Dead Rising 2 with a new main character.

												Dead Rising 2: Off the Record is a stand-alone expansion to Dead Rising 2. It is essentially a response to fans of the series who loved the second game but weren't big fans of the protagonist Chuck Greene and wanted a return of Frank West. In Off the Record you play as Frank West, the protagonist of the original Dead Rising. There are a lot of notable differences the two characters have compared to each other. Frank is a lovable charismatic scoundrel who largely looks out for his own self interest above all else. His animations are also different given how he's much pudgier. You go through mostly the same story and missions as the original, just with Frank instead of Chuck. Frank being the protagonist greatly improves the quality of the story to this game, and it feels like a more natural continuation of the original Dead Rising.The biggest differences between Off the Record and 2 is in the sidequests. The photography minigame from the original returns, alongside a very much improved endless mode. The endless mode is the biggest reason to pick this game up since Dead Rising 2 lacked it. It allows the player to explore Fortune City with no time limit and additional challenges. The user interface is also much improved.If you are a fan of the original Dead Rising 2 I guarantee you'll love Off the Record even more. It's exactly what fans of the series originally wanted and delivers in almost every way. I would even recommend it over the original release due to how similar the two experiences are to each other.One last thing to note is that Capcom graciously patched Games For Windows Live out of both this game and the original Dead Rising 2. So I would greatly recommend the Steam release for it is now the definitive version of the game.

Should I buy Dead Rising 2 or Dead Rising 2: Off The Record?This was the question I asked myself and researched about before purchasing this title.  In short, Off The Record is essentially the original Dead Rising 2 with more content, so if you've yet to play the original Dead Rising 2, or simply wish to enjoy the somewhat altered storyline and additional features, choose this title over the original. Pros:+ Zombies. Lots and lots of zombies+ Loads of weapons and weapon combinations+ Leveling system that keeps you going and allows for multiple playthroughs+ A decent sized mall / casino to explore and, you guessed it, kill lots and lots of zombies in+ Sandbox Mode*+ A surprisingly good storyline*Sandbox Mode is a unique feature to the Dead Rising series.  The Storyline timer is removed, allowing for unlimited exploration of Fortune City.  Challenge icons are scattered around Fortune City, rewarding you with either a bronze, silver or gold medal, depending on how well you completed said challenge.  Examples are "Kill as many zombies as you can in 3 minutes!" - "Get from point A to point B as fast as you can!", or, "Drink as much alcohol as you can in 5 minutes!".Sandbox Mode also allows you to carry over your stats to and from Storyline Mode, so if you're having trouble defeating a boss you can simply hop over to Sandbox Mode, level up, and jump back with everything you've gained from Sandbox Mode still intact (other than weapons and items).Middle Ground:~ Controls: Honestly, I'm not too sure how the keyboard and mouse hold up in this title as I've only played with an official Microsoft Xbox 360 controller (wired).  So as far as I can say, the controls via a controller are pretty decent.  Some unique moves are a little tricky to pull off properly at first, requiring awkward combinations of buttons to be pressed.  But the longer you play around with them the easier they become to execute, so the game does have somewhat of a learning curve as far as that goes.~Vehicles: The driving in this game was something I could never get used to; cars specifically.  They seem to go 0 to 60 in a split second, which doesn't work very well in an enclosed area.  Also, as far as I could tell, there isn't a handbrake, which makes trying to hit any sharp turns result in just crashing into the wall in front of you.  But seeing that driving isn't a requirement to complete the game, it's not such a big deal (and it is a lot of fun mowing over hordes of zombies in a sports car!).Cons:- Optimization: One of the biggest complaints I see about this game is it's poor optimization from being ported over from consoles, so the one thing I can recommend that you have in order to play this game somewhat smoothly is a decent CPU.  My GPU is garbage, but because I have a pretty decent CPU, I've had almost no problems from start to finish (other than slight frame sutters in areas with tons of zombies).Additional Thoughts:There is no doubt that the major complaint in this series is the storyline's timer.  Some people either feel too rushed or make the assumption that the game is meant to be 100% completed in one playthrough - the timer is intended to make you feel rushed; it adds urgency that the Sandbox Mode actually takes away.  It keeps you on your toes and forces you to make quick decisions (i.e., should I save that survivor or that one?  Should I go fight that boss or that one?).  This way, each time you play through the game's storyline it will be altered depending on your choices (the game also has multiple endings).Conclusion:I might be a little bias on this title as I absolutely love George A. Romero's Dawn Of The Dead (the Dead Rising series is heavily based off this movie); not only is it my absolute favorite zombie flick, it's also somewhere on my top 10 favorite movies of all time.  So, the concept of running around a zombie infested mall with dozens of weapons at one's disposal has always intrigued me, even before the original Dead Rising title was released.  If you're a fan of that movie, there is no reason for you not to pick up this game.

												There's a certain charm is firing lasers from your eyes; launching fireworks from a lead pipe and slaughtering inordinate amounts of zombies while choosing whatever you want to wear. If you like the idea of a slightly overweight middle aged reporter wearing a summer dress and a mask reminiscent of a LEGO piece; you can do that!The joys of the game come from how stupid the game is. Unlike almost every other zombie game which seeks to take itself seriously, Dead Rising recognises the humour that you can bring to a dark scenario. They don't bother with morbidity in this variation of the story and instead kick it to the curb in favour of juvenile humour. This game might try to tell you it has a "mature" age rating; but in actuality that would be like saying that alcohol can only be enjoyed by "mature" people. Once you're old enough to buy it, you aren't necessarily wise. The sense of humour is crude and trashy, which is part of the charm. That being said, it isn't much of a game for kids either. There is a copious amount of blood, mutilation and things which some people would say are unsafe for children. But it isn't for "adults" either. This is one of those games which isn't overtly mature but isn't something you'd give to a five year old. It's stupid and immature; which is the charm of the series. Dead Rising 1 tried to be serious and was "okay." Dead Rising 2 tried to make you care about characters which honestly didn't work for anyone. Off The Record fixes that problem in the same way that Saints Row 2 did. It stops trying to make things serious and meaningful and just says "why don't we make it fun instead?"Sandbox gives you the ability to just run around indefinitely and without consequence. You don't get forced to give a damn about giving Katie zombrex, you don't have to worry about survivors getting killed. Well, you kind of do but in a whole new way. You get to kill every survivor and you get paid for it. No more "oh damn I lost that survivor so now I have to load the last save." It becomes "sweet, I melted that survivors face off with my god damned laser eyes!" And in my opinion, that's all the series has needed. It NEEDED that stupidity and to stop caring about being meaningful and serious. If I had to recommend this game for one thing, it'd be for getting rid of any seriousness to it. It became stupid and that took away the thing I found most boring in it. So my advice is that if you're sick of Dead Rising being serious, this is the game you buy. If you want a meaningful and sensible zombie game, then look again. There are plenty of games that try to do that.

												I've spent hundreds of hours playing the Dead Rising series, and there are few games like it. Off the Record really has the most going for it. Dead Rising 2 fixed many issues that Dead Rising 1 had, and OtR polishes DR2 even further. It features all of DR2's famous weapons, plus the photography mechanic from DR1. Many dismiss photography as unnecessary to DR's gameplay, and I disagree. It's a comedic and gory game, and being able to take photos of the mayhem you cause and be rewarded for that turns that into a game mechanic. I can't count the times I wished I could have taken a photo of something unapologetically silly in vanilla DR2 and in DR3.Co-op mode is a lot of fun. Use the Invite button on the friends list from the in-game menu to ensure you get the partner you want, as the Play Online option on the main menu seems to be only for joining random people's games. The host player will be Frank West as in the single-player mode, while the client is Chuck Greene from vanilla DR2. Chuck's unarmed special moves are functionally similar to, but different from, Frank's, but that the only real difference to learn. He has a camera like Frank too, of course, so both players can take photos of each other doing outrageous things. There is no voice chat, however, so be ready to use Skype or something if you don't want to have to communicate by jumping and running around in circles. If you haven't played a Dead Rising before, are interested, but are unsure where to begin, I strongly recommend this one over any of the others, including DR3. Should you buy it if you already have DR2? I did, but only because I was buying the PC versions of the games I liked most on 360. For that I am glad it exists, but I wouldn't say there's a point to owning both if you wouldn't already have a reason to own two copies of the same game. It's a lot like when Pokémon comes out with the "third version" like Crystal that is both superior to, and essentially the same as, Gold and Silver.One last thing, though: getting it to support controllers is a pain. It has to be a specific version of x360ce. 2.0.2.158 is the one that's working for me and my wired 360 controller, but it doesn't work with my friend's Xbone controller even though it recognizes it.

												THIS GAME HAS MANY REPORTS OF POOR PERFORMANCE AND DUBIOUS CONTROLLER COMPATIBILITY IF YOU USE MULTIPLE MONITORS YOU WILL NEED 3RD PARTY SOFTWARE FOR THIS GAME TO RUN REASONABLYI'm running GTX 1080, i7 6700k, 16gb DDR4 ram and on my first run I was getting 5-10 FPS.Was also unable to use controller. Many have reported similar issues with this game.After doing research installed "Flawless Widescreen" which has specific plugin for DR2:OTR. This fixed all issues immediately, including controller support. I reccomend that you make sure this program is accessible if you use multiple monitors and otherwise be aware of potential performance issues. Now for the actual reviewThis game is a reimagining of DR2, which is already a good game. The main difference is a new protagonist, Frank West, who also brings with him a new main storyline more in the vein of the first game, and a variety of new/changed encounters and bossfights. Engine imrpovements are good, more zombies on screen and the additional content really finishes up the experience.For those who havent played DR2 or any other DR game, DR2:OTR is vaguely action-RPG mostly about time management. You are put in a mall (leisure resort thing with casinos, theme park, etc) and there are many zombies, and you must survive. You can use most objects of scenery as weapons, although most are fairly ineffective. There are a variety of wacky and fun items but they tend to be least effective as weapons as a trade off for being gruesome or silly. Items can be combined into better weapons, but again the entertaining ones (rocket powered wheelchair) tend to be barely effective in terms of gameplay. Things like Knifegloves or Fire-axe-Sledgehammer will be your go-to. Weapons degrade over time which encourages you to seek out good weaponry or be forced to use impromptu scenery in a pinch.The game is on a time limit, and while you can just survive till it runs out, you'll be given a variety of calls and objectives to go rescue survivors and uncover the conspiracy behind the game. This is the funnest part of the game; getting 2-3 calls on opposite ends of the mall and then dashing between them with survivors in tow to try and get everything done before the calls (and the game) times out. There is a degree of inventory management too, as the best weapons can be hard to produce, and healing items and magazines which provide buffs will take up precious space for weapons.Bossfights are varied and challenging, and show up in just the right numbers to prevent the game from getting boring. Bosses have patterns that must be learned and also vulnerabilities, some of which require getting creative (flamethrower boss can be easily beaten by water which stops his guns, or by cooking oil that sets him alight, or marbles that make him fall over, etc). Bosses also have interesting, if gimmicky characters to them too which can be entertaining or terrifiying. Dead Rising does not take itself overly seriously. Although there are a lot of nasty events, it tends to be weaved with a dark humour throughout most of them. There are some genuinely disturbing scenes (Randy, for instance) but even those tend to be with some sort of wacky scenario.Controls are generally tight but sometimes can be a bit awkward. Unlockable moves have difficult commands on controller (LT, RT, B held for 3 seconds while unequipped) and there is only one attack button (press for standard move, hold for strong attack) which can lead to missed inputs. Attacks tend to auto target enemies too which can lead to missed attacks or accidentally attacking survivors. First person aiming for throwing and ranged weapons can be difficult to use also.Zombies are slow and shambling; no special infected or anything. They are very basic and after a while barely threatening, but the theme of the game is how Frank develops to become a master of improvised zombie fighting, so if anything that is actually really appropriate. Frank will level up from kills, and by taking photographs of zombies, psychopaths and survivors, and by also just completing missions and such. This unlocks new abilites, moves, inventory slots and health slots.Also Online Co-op, although i havent had the oppurtunity to play with a friend recently. It worked very well when the game first came out btu I've heard reports of bad connectivity post-steamworks integration. No promises.Overall, Dead Rising 2 and Off the Record are games close to my heart. They are not like any other game series I can think of, with a very unique gameplay formula that makes them hard to define as a particular genre: action-RPG is a very vague title, I will admit. It is absolutely an RPG and it's easy to put many hours into it, trying to come up with new weapon combos or optimise your times from one area to another. Despite the performance issues (which I have shown how to resolve) the game is fantastic and I can see myself replaying it once or twice in the coming weeks, and then probably some more way off into the future.You will like DR2:OTR if :you like hectic gameplay against the clockyou like rpg-based gameplayyou enjoy wiping out tons of zombiesyou fancy trying out lots of wacky weapon combosyou want a game you can (and will probably have to) replay at least once or twice

												Dead Rising 2: Off The Record is basically Dead Rising 2 all over again (as the title suggests) but with some little changes here and there on how the story progresses, you can play as Frank West again, and in co-op your friends can play as Chuck Greene (the protagonist from the previous game).And even though the story and cutscenes are basically unchanged from the original game, Off The Record has some new content to offer, such as:- New weapons, new combo weapons, new clothes, new food items, new psychopaths, a new place to explore, a new ending and some rebalancing;- All the DLC from Dead Rising 2 is already included;- The re-addition of cameras so you can take funny pictures and share them with your co-op buddies;- A checkpoint system to remove even further the necessity of loading old save files; - Even more zombies on screen and some other minimal graphical changes.(These may actually decrease performance in some older PCs);- And last but not least, the "Sandbox Mode". This replaces the "Terror is Reality" game mode from Dead Rising 2. Sandbox Mode has absolutely no time limits, so you can do whatever you feel like doing! It also adds challenges for you to complete alone or with a friend, crazy survivors that attack you, and occasionally a psychopath will spawn just to keep things fresh.You're also able to share your progress directly with Story Mode, so if you're having a hard time progressing through some missions, you can just level up in Sandbox Mode and then go back to the main game.If you loved Dead Rising 2 and want more out of it or you just never even touched a game from this series, then this is certainly for you! But if you're looking for a completely different experience, then you might just pass on this one. PS: The game has been updated with trading cards, achievements, and now it uses Steamworks instead of Games For Windows Live.You can also import your older saves to this new version but unfortunately the achievements won't be carried over.If your save file is "corrupted" after importing to the new version, don't worry.Just follow the instructions presented in this discussion:https://steamcommunity.com/app/45770/discussions/0/615086038681380025/...And you should be good to go!

												This is my first foray into the Dead Rising series, so I can't really compare it to the others. I am also writing this review as I nominated it for the "Villain most in need of a hug" award, because there are so many characters in this game that need to find Jesus (or equivalent) haha!This particular game is a 3rd person adventure that takes place in Fortune City, a fictionalised place loosely based on Las Vegas with casinos, lights, and odd characters galore. Unfortunately however, a zombie outbreak occurs! Curiously, this is one of the few zombie games I've played where the zombies themselves are known about and already exist in the in-game world. So much so, that there is even a pharmaceutical drug called Zombrex that infected people in everyday life have to take to avoid becoming a zombie. However like I said, it gets a bit out of hand and the zombie situation spills beyond containable levels in the city. You being reporter Frank West, need to get to the bottom of this by getting out and about, leaving the sanctuary of your shelter.The game itself is very fun, with a semi-cliche, but serviceable plot. The slighty cheesiness of the plot actually adds to the game, given it's one that clearly doesn't take itself too seriously. One of the trademarks of this game is that you can craft a huge variety of sometimes ridiculous weapons from materials found around the map. Your character will eventually collect new recipes as you progress, but you can also discover them by just experimenting. You can hit a zombie with a bucket, or use an electric powerdrill on it, or you can combine them to create a 'brain bucket' that minces any unfortunate zombie you make wear it. There's also a wide variety of different clothing combinations your character can pick up around the map.There's also LOTS of zombies, but on the whole, they're quite docile. You, and more likely your NPC partners that follow you in parts of the game, can still get mobbed, but the massive hoard of zombies (at least initially) are fairly slow compared to some other games. At least initially anyway...There's also quite a number of boss-like fights either as part of the main story or side-plots or events (known as Psychopaths). I found there to be a good variety between them, and some of the Psychopaths in particular are hilarious (my favourite being the Postman and Randy). Unfortunately, the game isn't exactly without issues. It sometimes feels a bit clunky, and while technically open world, you actually get put under time pressure in the story mode if you want to do everything that comes up (and there's quite a few things). There is a sandbox mode to address this somewhat though which is nice, but not quite the same as a story mode with slightly more flexible timing in my opinion.Also, apparently this game used to rely on GWFL, and when it was moved off that, all the DLC stopped working/appearing and this issue was never fixed. While the DLC doesn't seem to be a big deal, this kind of laziness doesn't really put the game in good light.Overall though, I had fun with this game and would still recommend it. It usually falls to quite low prices, so be sure to get it on sale!

												So, I have been a fan of the series for quite some time. When I was younger, I had a PS3 and really wanted to get an Xbox 360 just to play Dead Rising 1. Dead Rising 1 was absolutely amazing and I loved everything about it. I also pre-ordered Dead Rising 2 for the PS3 when it came out. Dead Rising 2 was good and added a larger mall, combo weapons, and many more secrets and hidden items. And it all comes down to this game, Dead Rising 2: Off the Record. This has improved a bit from Dead Rising 2 by including even more combo weapons, a new vehicle, and my favorite feature, the protagonist as Frank West. Frank actually put on a few pounds after the 5-6 years between the Willamette outbreak and the second Fortune City outbreak. But, this game is a great game to get even for its old release date. If you want to get a good idea about the story, you should maybe start out with Dead Rising 1 or 2. But buy this game if you want to have a lot of fun killing zombies and playing co-op. What is also a great reason to purchase this game is that yesterday it got Steamworks!!!! So you can just join your friends through Steam instead of GFWL (Games for Windows Live). Overall, this is amazing game to get started on the series with, and I will give it a 9/10 because of how much it improved switching to Steamworks. Buy this game whenever it goes on sale and you will have A LOT of fun.

												Dead Rising 2: OTR (SP Only) *** Combining DR2 and DR2:OTR ***Story (5/10): DR2: OTR's story is largely the same as the other two DR installments. A somewhat bland story, sometimes perked by Capcom's characteristically silly character interactions. Overall, not a strong point of the game.Gameplay (7/10): DR2: OTR delivers the same Dead Rising experience that fans of the series have come to know, and sometimes love. Hordes of zombies flood the screen, and as usual, your job is to smite them using a variety of crazy weapons, ranging from laser shooting masks to chainsaw-tipped kayak paddles. DR2 and DR2:OTR really picked up from DR in the sense that they added a LOT of new weapons, which helps the game keep fresh throughout its duration. It personally never got old to smash through piles of enemies using an ever-expanding arsenal of ridiculous armaments. The added infinite mode is worth looking into, since you are unbound by the time constraints of the normal game, and given challenges to complete for money and xp, which carries over into the main game. This can be helpful if you are stuck in the main storyline.Unfortunately, this is where the fun ends. As with previous DR installments, boss fights are tedious and cheap, escorts are constant and frustrating, and many parts of the game feel drawn out and devoid of content or direction. If you are not satisfied with killing zombies, you will find little else of value in this game.Mechanics (6/10):DR2/DR2:OTR's new mechanic is the weapon combination mechanic, which allows you to combine weapons into new devastating combinations. This system is unfortunately limited by your need to find/unlock blueprints to use combo weapons to their full potentional, as well as the need to find specific "maintenance rooms" where the combos can be made. A more on-the-fly system may have been easier. Otherwise, mechanics remain somewhat unchanged from DR1, and are as usual, buggy and unforgiving.Visuals (7/10): DR2:OTR looks decent, probably mediocre, by today's standards. Edges are clean, textures are not obviously stretched out or degraded, and lighting effects are present to some degree. The technical prowess of the game comes from its ability to maintain hundreds of enemies on-screen at the same time, which still remains impressive, and a trademark of the series.Sound (7/10): The only comment I have about the sound is the game's tendency to have the constant moan of zombies drown out all other noise. It gets tiresome. Otherwise, the game does not have any noticeable sound achievements or problems.Replayability (9/10): DR2:OTR are both strong contenders in the "Replayability" category. There are a lot of weapons to unlock, skills to upgrade, and powerful costumes to unlock (especially the famous Zero armor, from Megaman). After beating the main game, I went through a second time, in order to beat down my opponents using a souped-up Frank West, complete with overpowered weapon combinations. Very satisfying.OVERALL: DR2:OTR is a fun, satisfying game, held back by poorly implemented mechanics, a buggy nature (see: Capcom games), and perhaps a lack of foresight. Do you like zombies? Do you like killing them? Tons of them? PILES of them? Yes? Then you'll love this game.7/10

												I am trying hard to like this game, but there's a dozen little annoyances that keep it held back from being a reccomendation to anyone except Dead Rising fans.  I hate to say this game is garbage, but I've been screaming at the monitor for all its gameplay flaws after 10+ hours.1.  The Survivor AI is terrible and they're a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to manage.  It's every nightmare you always think of with Escort Missions.  Almost half the characters you find can't use a gun, 1/8 of all of them can't use melee and take up an inventory slot for you to carry them.  You get surrounded by zombies way too easily even if you give them a gun.  Don't even try if you have a group of survivors because they'll just shoot through and even kill other survivors.  (The Leadership Buff didn't help either.)  If they get grabbed, it stops the entire pace of you running through the constant thick crowd of zombies and you have to rescue them.  If you didn't notice them getting grabbed, hit the restart checkpoint option becaues they'll definitely die with how fast their health goes down.  (You WILL hit Restart Checkpoint A LOT.)2.  You take damage too easily from the bosses.  You will constantly try to find or keep health items during any boss fight because they can take off half your life bar in seconds.  You will have to constantly pick at them because several can regen their health.  And ♥♥♥♥ those Militia Hunters in the central plaza.  Rapid firing sniper rifle ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who you WILL have to lame it out with eather going for rapid melee or peek shooting from behind the air vents.  Seriously, as soon as you see their introductory cutscene (they're the group of sterotypical rednecks with Berrett Jacksons), go to the Dead Rising Wikia entry on Hunters for their Locations.  You will have to take them out immediately since you go through the central plaza all the time and survivors will be shot too.  Each bullet takes off 1/4 survivor health and you can't stop them.Then I got to the sheriff after them who could shoot guns out of my hands.  This gimmick boss♥♥♥♥♥♥is super frustrating and is the one time I'd recommend to anybody of finding a way to cheat to get infinite health JUST for the bosses.  You really do have to find a way to lame it out or read the Wikia on tactics to beat them.  Their AI is pretty exploitable at times, but the cheap gimmicks make them frustrating.3.  It's increidbly hard to enjoy the environment or exploring because of the constant time sensitive objectives.  I'd recommend Sanbox mode first just to memorize the locations, finding the secret caches of good weapons, and read how to unlock the shortcuts.  There is a gunshop on the right side of the map called High Noon Something.4.  The zombies should have thinned out.  I know it's part of the game franchise, but the zombie hordes are THICK.  You will have a tough time just trying to avoid getting swiped or grabbed because they're everywhere, unavoidable, and using weapons slows you down, making you even more of a target.  Try getting any powerful rapid fire and AOE weapons like the Rocket Launcher, the parasol blower combo, or Queens.  Don't use normal melee weapons for anything except as a last resort.5.  There seems to be a lot of engine optimization failures and it's inherent in the series.  There's a lot of fade in as you move from one area to the next things faze out of existence all the time.  It's either because of the team that designed this series isn't experienced enough to optimize well, or it's just part of the sub par PC port.  (The same problem is within DR3 as well.)  The framerate doesn't♥♥♥♥♥♥itself hard like it does in DR3, but it can be noticable in thick areas.  I haven't had that problem since I have a powerful PC, but there are other problems like lack of a Windowed mode.  The blanking of both my PC monitors for 5 seconds going into and out of DR2 along with the lag and potential crashing is the reason why I always support PC games having a Windowed mode.  This is inexcusable.For the positives, what can I say, it's a Dead Rising game and a spin-off title that takes place in the same universe as the normal DR2, except this one has Frank West as the main protagonist.  Surprisingly, there are people who still play in co-op in this game, but I haven't been able to join or receive someone.  I'm not sure if it's the probelm with Games For Windows Live API or something, but it's a little screwy.  This is really one of those games that needs a difficulty setting because I feel like I'm playing on Hard Mode the entire time and it's kicking my♥♥♥♥♥  I'm not sure how long I can play this, but I'm not coming back after this.

Essentially the same game... Originally posted by DR2 review:Dumb & simple zombie killing fun. Like the first game, weapons and health are generally all around you only this time around you can combine two specific items to make another weapon that's possibly cooler, sillier, practical, or a combination of a number of those. You can find out what item goes with what via Combo Cards which are unlocked through general progression of the game such as examining certain posters, leveling, defeating psychopaths, etc. You can combine items without the specific card however the item produced won't be as effective and rewarding. It's highly encouraging to produce the Combo Weapons because using them generally nets you PP for leveling and curiosity in how they'll work will become pretty high.You're free to run around the world as you please (aside from some areas that can only unlocked from doing certain missions) though its criticized time limit makes a return so you only have so much time to get to doing the missions. If you stick to doing missions, not be as distracted, and perhaps if you're at a decent level it won't feel like it's rushing you to go do something so much. Even if you fail a task no matter how important and until the timer runs out or you choose to restart the story you're free to run around freely doing whatever. Restarting the specific save file's story allows you to keep your level, money, and Combo Cards for that next playthrough.The plot & dialogue is full of cheese, especially with the psychopaths. I think it's for the better that that's the case.There isn't much depth to the actual zombie killing aside from just having good weapons for the situation and the psychopath fights. The psychopaths can be extremely cheap in their own special way but at least for most of the fights you're free to leave and return to the area in case you don't feel ready for the boss fight. The co-op's overall doable. A bit easier (if no lag is present) but adds enjoyment to the game. The money and level you've earned anywhere in a save file can be used in both single player and co-op where the only thing that doesn't carry over for either is the story if you're not hosting the game. The entire thing could have probably used an implemented in-game chat and give-item-to-partner feature as opposed to dropping or chucking the item for them to pick it up.Fetch quests, escorts, and just messing around. Probably better with a controller since keys are unrebindable....but now it's slightly not as optimized, there's a new area for you to explore, some new items & Combo Weapons, some new survivors, many familiar items and survivors have been relocated for better or worse, the story's a teensy bit altered, there's a "Sandbox Mode" for you to run amok in without fear of a timer where your progress in it carries over to the story mode and vice versa, and now you take control of a photojournalist who's covered wars.

												It's Dead Rising 2 again, except Frank West returns along with his own original move set and attack animations, the story is shuffled around a little and there's a whole new area in the city - a space-themed amusement park. There's also a couple of new weapons (including combo weapons), a couple of new bosses, and a handful of gameplay changes, the things I remember the most being:- Frank is infected and needs Zombrex every 24 hours, but he can inject himself no matter where he is, which removes the element of rushing back to the safehouse every day for Katey- Frank's picture-taking mechanic returns- If you're lightly damaged while holding a weapon you can't store in your inventory (say, a Gem Blower), you won't always drop it. You'll still drop it if you get knocked down, though.The co-op is even better than before, because Player 2 still plays as Chuck Greene (still using his own move set and attack animations) and him and Frank have a fair amount of dialogue for shouting at one another. They're really rude to each other for no reason at all, which is really funny."Hey, zombie boy! I've got your drug!" -Chuck (the actual reason being the dialogue was recorded for DR2: Case West - an X360-exclusive expansion (thanks capcom) - where the two of them start off on the wrong foot)Oh, and let's not forget about the Sandbox mode! In this mode, you're free to just goof off with no time limits to worry about. You're free to carry over levels, PP and money you earn in Sandbox to the 72-hour mode and vice versa. Most of the bosses will spawn in their usual places at certain times, but the friendly survivors are now hostile and will spawn in set places and attack you. There's also challenges around the map, with objectives like earning large numbers of PP, luring zombies to a specific area, racing to a finish point, or just plain killing zombies, so that gives you something to do besides just mucking around and exploring, which is still always fun.It's not as good of a port as the original DR2, which in itself was only an okay port, but it's still not too bad. The most notable thing is that you can't turn depth of field off without hex editing, but it runs a little better after you disable that.+ It's still DR2 - Still fun and funny, music's still good, the city still looks nice, co-op is still incredibly fun+ The new additions and subtractions are generally welcome, most notably Sandbox mode- It's still DR2 - Still kind of buggy and rickety and immature, having to earn speed upgrades by leveling up is still a huge pain- It really didn't need to be a seperate, full-priced game- DOF8/10This game (and the base game) have some of the most hilarious co-op action I've ever experienced. The single player experience is great, too.

												So yeah. This is my first review, but then, this is one of the games I know intimately well. I may only have about 16 hours on record here, but I've logged far more on the 360 version.The Dead Rising series seems a bit schlocky, and that's not surprising. It's meant to be a tongue-in-cheek take on zombie outbreaks. It remains serious enough to have a cohesive plot, but not so serious that a lot of the bosses and scenarios you encounter seem far-fetched or histrionic.The fun very much comes from having a whole playground of casinos, mall shops, and an added amusement park to formulate weapons and combat them. In addition to that, you'll encounter a lot of survivors who need to be brought back to the safehouse.Then there's the sandbox mode. It takes out the merciless clock and timer that often impeded your missions in Dead Rising 2 and the original Dead Rising. That really allows for it to be your playground.There's a bit of humor, a bit of sexy, a 'reality' TV show that glorifies zombie-killing in a WWE-type format. And what's more: Frank West returns in the Off the Record rendition.Some of its reviews both here and elsewhere tend to be a bit negatory because DR2:OTR took so very much from DR2... so much that, heck, a lot of it's exactly the same. But what OTR really does is fine-tune, improve, and give a little more freedom. It makes it a lot more fun. It's what kept me coming back. I've probably played through the story twenty to thirty times now... and I expect to keep going. The ride's that fun.Grab a weapon. Get creative. Explore. You'll find plenty of crazies along the way.

												Disclaimer: This is a review I wrote when the game was new, copied from another site. It was based off my time with the Xbox 360 version and I've only put in a short time on the PC version. So issues with GFWL or it's removal are NOT taken into account. From 2011. *****************************************************************************************************************OK let me preface this by saying that I am a Dead Rising fanboy. A major one. I am well aware of all the games flaws and issues and I couldn't care less. I enjoyed the first Dead Rising like no game before it. As a huge fan of Romero films and zombie fiction of all kinds, Dead Rising was the first game I felt truly captured the feeling of an oppressive "Zombie Event". And of course the parallels to Dawn of the Dead didn't hurt it either. The original Dawn is a timeless classic that has been a high water mark for decades and it's remake holds the unique position of being just as good as the film that it's based on.Fast Forward from 2006 to 2010 and Dead Rising 2. I was initially shocked that Frank was not planned for the sequel of Dead Rising. But with time and some gameplay I warmed up to Chuck Green. The Combo Weapon system was great and the irreverant humor from the original was well intact. For my money, it was another success. But I never did stop missing Frank despite putting upwards of 30 hours into DR2 and even more into Case Zero and Case West.Now on to the reason for this write up, Off the Record (hereafter; 'OtR'). OtR is a curious title, even for me. Being the big fan of zombie games, of Dead Rising 1, and of Frank West, I was on board with this one from the word GO. The problem though, is who other than me would even consider this game a valid purchase? And releasing in one of the most cluttered fall release schedules since 2007? This game just doesn't seem to have an audience outside of the insane DR fans like myself, and even for us it's starting to feel like Capcom is pulling another Street FIghter 2 here with constant reiterations instead of moving on. And all in the span of 13 months.The game itself is pretty great. The same formula that made the other Dead Rising products enjoyable is still here with some nice new additions. Serious fans will enjoy the subtle changes to make the protagonist swap fit and there have been adjustments to the looters and the zombies seem more aggressive than in the other DR games. New combo weapons and the return of the camera mechanic round out a pretty impressive list of "Pros" for this game.The issue at hand though, is the list of "Cons". No matter how fun it may be, if you played DR2 proper, this is just not enough of an upgrade for the casual fan to embrace. The hardcore DR nut will love OtR but I wonder just how many of us there are and if we number high enough to make this game profitable?I've been a big supporter of this series. And I've always done my best to try and steer people to playing it. Forum posts asking "What 360 games should I play?" always see me trumpetting Dead Rising and Dead Rising 2's greatness. This game though, I just don't think I can be it's emmisary. I cannot "sell" this game to people. If you're on board, you were already on board and if you're on the fence, I'm not going to be trying to push you over. It is a good game. And on paper it's probably the best Dead Rising to date. But even with all the good stuff it has to offer (not the least of which is finally adding the checkpoint system fans have been wanting since 2006!), I just can't push a game like this. While it's a 5 star for me personally, I can't even imagine that anyone else would share that view of this one.To Bottom Line it, it's a great fun romp though a zombie outbreak with a charasmatic protagonist. It's just that the romp is basically the same one you took last year with DR2 proper. OtR can only truly be recommended to either those who never played DR2, or who are major Frank West fans who are willing to overlook the fact that they already played this game a year ago. It's definately a curious animal, but I doubt most people will feel the need to have it on their mantle.

												As somebody who owns and has played both Dead Rising 2 and Dead Rising 2: Off the Record, I will be comparing it to Dead Rising 2Pros:More Combo weaponsTaking PicturesNew BossesSandbox ModeFrank West's humourConcept art galleryCons:New Bosses: As much as I like the replacement for the Leon Bell fight (not saying who his replacement is), the new final boss is worse in all aspects. It feels like one big gimmick, and since all of the buildup for Dead Rising 2's twist boss is unchanged, the new boss just comes off as forced. Whereas the other new boss is just lame and annoying with bland music.More bugs, ranging from helpful (infinite paddlesaw) to irritating (Weapons clipping through the floor) to even horrendous (getting stuck on things)Online is worseNo graphics optionsRemoval of Terror is Reality (far from a dealbreaker imo)Overall, I prefer Dead Rising 2, but Off the Record from pure content is a better game. I prefer 2's storytelling, though Off the Record does have it's moments of great narrative (working Brandon into the main story was cool). If you just want story and some fun get 2, but if you want more ways to kill zombies and more time to kill zombies(or just even if you enjoyed 2) I recommend Off the Record.
